data:
Facsimile Images

Dum esset sacerdos Syriae deae
Tiberius Tiberii f(ilius)
pontifex fil(ius) Dapsili
Amphilobi vero Paeadia qui fuit Theodori qui fuit
5Morrecini qui iusta fecere
praesides Syriae deae singulis annis
P(ublius) plonus P(ubli) filius
M(arcus) Pomponius di[---]
L(ucius) Lucinius [---]
10L(ucius) Octavius L[---]
T(itus) Phaecius [---]
Attale [---]
Eutich[---]

Apparatus criticus

Text after IG with slight changes

translation

commentary

The text is only recorded by Octavius Caietanus (1566-1620) in his 'Isagoge ad historiam sacram siculam' (published posthumously in 1707), where he simply describes it as a 'tabella mamorea Syracusis reperta graeco idiomate', which he renders in Latin. 'Amphilobi' clearly refers to an 'amphipolos'. It clearly bears close similarity to the inscriptions for Anna and the Paides from Buscemi (cf. ISic002997 or 002999), and given that and the Latin names, is probably of the early first century CE.

bibliography

    Caietanus 1707 19-20 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002774 14.0009 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001072 3.5372 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001252 Tusa 1963 189 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001540 Wilson 1990 300 with n.102 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001509 Sfameni Gasparro 1973 162-164 no.358 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001586
